EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Signal Hill Petroleum has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Gas Processing System.  Signal Hill Petroleum's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility utilizes the Gas Processing System to process natural gas that is supplied from the field.  Process Safety Information contains the inventory calculations for the system.  



Risk Considerations

Although the storage and processing of flammables has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Signal Hill Petroleum has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the company and facility personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.  In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a flammable release:

-There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.

-The system undergoes scheduled maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

-Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by facility personnel, as necessary.

-A well designed relief system

 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were d

ocumented and implemented by Signal Hill Petroleum to manage process safety issues associated with the processing of flammables. Prevention Program 3 elements are listed below:

2760.1     Process Safety Information (PSI) 

2760.2     Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

2760.3     Operating Procedures (OP)

2760.4     Training (TRN)

2760.5     Mechanical Integrity (MI)

2760.6     Management of Change (MOC)

2760.7     Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)

2760.8     Compliance Audits (CA)

2760.9     Incident Investigation (II)

2760.10 Employee Participation (EP)

2760.11 Hot Work Permit (HWP)

2760.12 Contractors (CON)

Article 7  Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No reportable accidents have occurred within the last 5 years.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ASSESSMENT

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7(q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of flammables were addressed by the November 2010 Process Hazard Analysis for the system.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:

Description of the types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  

- During the Process Hazard Analysis, a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  However, the Team only deemed some of these events as being credible, and fully developed those scenarios that present an opportunity for flammables release.  The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

- A seismic safety walk-down was performed in January 2011 and the report is behind the

SEISMIC ASSESSMENT Tab in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.

- The magnitude of the external events considered is detailed within the Process Hazard Analysis Worksheets.

For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply  

- The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

- Major hazards identified;

- Process controls in use;

- Mitigation systems in use;

- Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,

- Changes since the last PHA.

- The recommendations precipitating from the Process Hazard Analysis are summarized in Attachment B of the Process Hazard Analysis report in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.  All recommendations were assigned an expected completion date.

- The Human Factors discussed in the Process Hazard Analysis are documented as a separate node.  The worksheets can be found in Attachment C of the Process Hazard Analysis report, including major hazards identified, process controls in use, mitigation systems in use, and monitoring and detection systems in use.

- There were no significant changes since the last Process Hazard Analysis.

The date of the most recent field verification that equipment is installed and maintained as designed.

- The most recent field verification of equipment is conducted as a part of the facility's routine inspection and walk down schedule.



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined for the process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

Scenario Description: A realistic alternative release scenario was defined for the process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Signal Hill Petroleum has implemented an Emergency Action Plan and does not ass

ume the role of first responder during an emergency. Signal Hill Petroleum has filed a plan with the Los Angeles County Fire Department and this plan includes:

- Emergency Alarm Procedures

- Evacuation Procedures

- Safety and Health Considerations

- Notification Procedures



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Signal Hill Petroleum is extremely diligent in the handling of flammables. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the PHA Report which can be found behind the PHA Tab in the CalARP Compliance Workbook.
